you have a lot of other stuff going on

things around replacing our hosts based

long time did about 2000 code releases
while running at least part of the stack
in parallel if it takes an extra 10
minutes to do the deployments to both of
those stacks that's actually 47 working
days to do all those releases so you
know you pay a cost when you're running
stuff in parallel as soon as you have a
lot of services and then we had to make
some decisions about how we were going
to run in parallel we started off by
thinking about how are we going to
commit changes and in our proof of
concept we had a cube Letty's changes on
a separate branch and I'm sure anyone
that's ever been stuck in merge hell
will realize that that's a bad idea we
very quickly decided that that was just
going to diverge too much and it would
be too painful to try and maintain it so
he said everything has to go on to the
same branch but that means you now start
deploying changes to your life stack
purely to support the fact that you're
building this other stack so that is a
risk it's a risk you have to decide with
you're ok with our risk the second thing
was around deployment
if you have completely separate
deployment mechanisms for two stacks you
can absolutely guarantee things will get
out of sync because someone will forget
to do the deployment for one of the two
and if you've got 150 services it's
actually quite hard to scan and see that
you're out of sync but running a single
pipeline is risky because you don't want
to block and emergently emergency
deployment to your live stack because
someone got something wrong on your new
experimental stack so in the end we kind
of compromised both deployments were
kicked off by tagging a release in
github deployments to lower environments
are done automatically and we had a push
button okay
go policy for putting it to the
kubernetes stack and then we wrote a
service that would basically compare the
versions and report on the differences
and we just ran that manually every
couple of days and then said look you
forgot to deploy this testing is another
area where you can get really sucked in
you don't want to have to test
everything in two places so we focused
on the live stack we did very little
testing as we went on the fibonacci
stack but we had some things that really
helped us here that we'd built for our
staging environment we just used them
now for the new stack first of all we
had every event about publishing content
that goes through our production stack
we can also send it off to any other

both and that meant that if it failed we

secondly we have a load replicator that

not quite working and then at the end we
did a big enter end-to-end testing
effort so running in parallel it is
costly second thing I wanted to talk

that's ten days of work but the changes

pretty
for don't know we're just basically

that we'd have things were
Porter's being down when in fact they
